text: Welcome to MothEd! Together over the next few weeks we're going to get to research moths. Here in CLUE, we'll record our work and we can choose to share it with our group and the class.
Drawing
What are moths? They are a type of insect, and we will learn more about them as we go along. But first... please make a drawing of a moth using a card and markers. Then,

1. On the back of your drawing, write some words that describe the moth.
  2. Take a picture of your drawing, and a picture of the words you wrote on the back.
  3. Put your name on the back of the drawing and hand it in to your teacher.
To add your drawing to CLUE,

1. Click the image button in your workspace to create a tile that can hold an image
  2. Drag the image of your drawing to the image tile
  3. Create another image tile for the image of the back of the card, and drag the image onto the tile.
That's it! You've added your drawings to CLUE.
Group work
First, make sure all the members of your group have the same group number at the top right of your screen.
We’re here to learn about moths together. What do you know about moths?
Talk about what you know about moths with your group. Take notes and make a list in your workspace.
Next, find some photos of moths online. Save them to your desktop and drag them into image tiles.
Have each person quickly introduces themself with their first name (“I’m Amanda or Miss Amanda, and I teach about bugs”)
We will tell also introduce the camera equipment.
The first task asks students to draw moths. If they ask, “What is a moth?” we can tell them a moth is a type of insect. They should draw what they think a moth might be.
Students should each do their own drawing without looking at other folks’ drawings and without talking.
Share
Use the group controls so that you can see and share each others' notes and images. See the image below for how to do that.

Divide class into small groups of 4 or less. Make sure each group is in the same Group shown in the top right of the screen. If they aren't, have them click the group number, leave, and join whichever group number they are assigned.
It's important that students record their own and each others exact words, not an interpretation from an adult.
Discuss what you see in the images with your group. Add anything you'd like to your notes.

Watch Seven Spectacular Moths and write down what you notice in a text tile (letter A at right). Please note, this is a placeholder video only. If your school does not allow access to YouTube, it will not load. We will place videos on accessible servers for the actual curricular materials .]
Explore moth diversity and morphology
Take a careful look at the Types Of Moths display below. Enter your notes into a text tile (letter A at right). Make as MANY observations as you can:

• What do you notice? (Wing size, wing shape, wing color(s), body size, body texture, antenna size, antenna type, etc.)
  • How do you know you are looking at moths?
  • What are some things that all the moths have in common?
  • What are differences or variations?
  • It is important to know how many kinds of moths live in an area, since different kinds of moths do different things -- how do we tell the different kinds of moths apart?
When you and your group mates are done, click the "Share" button (upper right) so the group can see your list and you can see theirs.

With your group, review each list. Select one of you to be the Recorder and build a group list of all the observations (drag and drop) to share with the class. Recorders can publish the group list when ready.
Virtual Gallery Walk - did any group notice anything your group missed? Add anything you like to your own list by dragging the tile from other groups' content in Class Work.
